docs.lead_paragraph: In a study that may offer new evidence of the hazards of secondhand tobacco smoke, researchers have found that people who are exposed to it may be more likely to develop diabetes. Previous studies offered mixed results about whether smokers are more prone to the disease. But the current report, in the online edition of the journal BMJ, found that smokers and people who are regularly exposed to smoke are at risk.

headline.main: Doctors Link Diabetes and Secondhand Smoke

docs.abstract: Dr Thomas K Houston of Birmingham Veterans Affairs Medical Center leads study on hazards of second-hand smoke; research, which is published in journal BMJ, finds that people exposed to smoke are more likely to develop diabetes than those people who are not around smoke on regular basis; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Getting too little sleep may be a significant risk factor for high blood pressure. In a study of more than 4,800 men and women, people ages 32 to 59 who got five hours of sleep a night or less were about 60 percent more likely to develop hypertension than those who slept six to eight hours.

headline.main: Research Ties Lack of Sleep To Risk for Hypertension

docs.abstract: Dr James E Gangwisch, Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health postdoctoral fellow, leads study that suggests people who do not get adequate sleep may be more likely to develop high blood pressure; research is published in journal Hypertension (M)

headline.main: For Adults, Allergies Bring a Surprising Twist

docs.abstract: Experts say that adult-onset allergies are on rise in United States; hold that causes could include imbalanced immune system or increased exposure to indoor allergens; explain that adult allergy sufferers may never be treated for symptoms, either because they do not recognize they have allergies or because they are resistant to taking medication because of fear of unwanted side effects; treatment options discussed; drawing (M)
